text_paragraphs: Information Note on the Court’s case-law

Plaintiff in proceedings relating to social rights unable to obtain a copy of the written opinion of a representative of the Attorney-General's department at the Supreme Court or to reply to it, and presence of that representative at the court's private sitting: violation

[This summary is extracted from the Court’s official reports (Series A or Reports of Judgments and Decisions). Its formatting and structure may therefore differ from the Case-Law Information Note summaries.]
Nature of functions of Attorney-General's department at Supreme Court: to assist the court, help ensure that its case-law was consistent and to uphold the public interest.

Great importance of part actually played in proceedings by member of Attorney-General's department: his submissions contained an opinion designed to advise and accordingly influence the Supreme Court - what had been at stake for the applicant in the proceedings before that court - fact that it had been impossible for applicant to obtain a copy of the opinion before judgment was given and to reply to it had infringed his right to adversarial proceedings.

Presence of member of Attorney-General's department at Supreme Court's private sitting had afforded, if only to outward appearances, an additional opportunity to bolster his opinion without fear of contradiction.
Complaint that Supreme Court had been neither impartial nor independent - no need for a ruling.
Complaint not reiterated before the Court: no need for it to be considered of Court's own motion.
Conclusion: unnecessary to rule on the complaint (unanimously).
A.	Damage: sufficiently compensated by the finding of a breach.
Conclusion: respondent State to pay a specified sum for costs and expenses (unanimously).
